STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 1, 2024
Romell G Green
Wayne County DHHS – South Central
1801 E. Canfield St.,
Detroit, MI, 48207-4635
Re: License #: CP820201496
Dear Mr. Green:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
2/2/2024. An Exit conference was held with your agency on 2/9/2024. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
Enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP820201496
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Romell G Green
Name of Agency: WAYNE COUNTY DHHS - SOUTHCENTRAL
Agency Address: 1801 E CANFIELD ST
DETROIT, MI 48207-4635
Agency Telephone #: 3135785102
Original Issuance Date: 09/03/1993
License Effective Date: 2/1/2023
License Expiration Date 1/31/2025
Service Types: Supervise Independent Living, Place children
in foster home
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 1/25/2024, 1/26/2024, 2/1/2024 & 2/2/2024

Unlicensed relative homes 71 4

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
In 1 of 20 employee records reviewed where the employee was promoted, the
record showed the employee's six month evaluation due by 4/2/2023, was
completed late on 1/24/2024.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Interim inspection, with the corrective
plan approved on 4/18/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement.
(6) An agency must document, in the child's record,
within 7 calendar days after placement, the information
specified in R 400.12417(1) and all the following
information:
(a) All the following child characteristics:
2

(iii) Height and weight.
(iv) Eye color and hair color.
(v) Identifying marks.
(vi) Religious or spiritual preference.
4 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of(iii) –(vi) as
required by the rule. The information was not entered.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into an
out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of the last
physical examination.
2 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the child’s initial trauma screening due by 11/3/2023
was completed over 2 months late on 1/18/2024.
• A second record showed the child's medical due by 11/19/2023 was
completed 31 days late on 12/20/2023.
Repeat Violations
(c)- Cited during the 2022 Interim inspection, with the corrective plan
approved on 4/18/2022.
(i) Cited under FOM 802 during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective plan approved on 1/27/2023 and during the 2022 Interim inspection
with the corrective action plan approved on 4/18/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3
months before entry into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more than 90
3

calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam within 3 months of
his or her first birthday.
In 1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed, the record showed the child's initial
dental exam due by 1/2/2024 was not documented.
Repeat Violation-Cited during the 2022 Interim inspection, with the corrective
plan approved on 4/18/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at least
every 9 months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
In 1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed, the record showed the child's dental re-
examination due by 11/16/2023 was completed over 2 months late on 1/22/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (c), (e), (f)
and (g) as required by the rule related to 4 placement changes.
Additionally, this record did not show documentation of (d) as required by the rule
related to the child’s initial placement; nor the child’s 4 other placement changes.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
4

(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
1 of 7 initial service plans reviewed showed the child's 6/29/2023-7/28/2023 initial
service plan was completed 4 days late on 8/2/23.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
1 of 12 updated service plans reviewed showed the child’s 8/24/2023-11/22/2023
updated service plan was completed 13 days late on 12/5/2023.
Repeat Violation-Cited during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on1/27/2023; and during the 2022 Interim
inspection, with the corrective plan approved on 4/18/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
3 of 7 initial service plans reviewed did not show documentation of (c) as required
by the rule.
Repeat Violation-Cited during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023; and during the 2022 Interim
inspection, with the corrective plan approved on 4/18/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
5

is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.
In 1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed, where siblings were split, the record did
not show documentation of a July or August 2023 sibling visit.
FOM 722-6 B Family Team Meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required
time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be combined with
the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM. Updated Case Plan
(USP) – within 30 calendar days before the case plan due
date. Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Semi-annual transition meeting:
Beginning at age 14, semi-annual transition meetings
must occur once every 180-calendar day to discuss a
child’s permanency goal and identify supportive adults.
4 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child’s initial
service plan (ISP) or 8/24/2022-11/22/2023 updated service plan (USP).
Also, this record did not show documentation of an FTM for a 10/20/2023
change of placement. Nor of a DHS-1105 for a reported FTM on 5/25/2023.
• A second record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child’s ISP.
Nor documentation of an FTM for the child’s 10/11/2023-1/4/2024 USP.
• A third record did not show documentation of semi-annual transition meeting
in 2023.
• A fourth record did not show documentation of an DHS-1105 for an FTM
reported for 10/20/2023 and 11/16/2023.
6

Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on1/27/2023; and during the 2022 Interim
inspection, with the corrective plan approved on 4/18/2022.
FOM 722- 8D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker.
• Supervisor.
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
6 of 19 services plans reviewed (related to 3 of 8 open foster child cases reviewed)
did not show compliance:
• One record showed the child’s 8/25/2023-11/22/2023 USP was not signed by
the caregiver. The agency showed documentation the birth parent signed this
treatment plan after the required time on 2/4/2024.
• A second record did not show documentation of the caregiver’s signature on
the child’s 7/3/2023-8/1/2023 ISP; and the caregiver’s signature on the child’s
8/2/2023-10/10/2023 USP was not dated. The agency showed
documentation that the birth mother signed this child’s ISP and USP on
1/31/2024, both outside the required time frame.
• A third record showed the youth did not sign the 12/10/2022-3/10/2023;
3/11/2023-6/9/2023; and 6/9/2023-9/6/2023 USPs until 2/7/2024, all outside
the required time frame.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on1/27/2023; and during the 2022 Interim
inspection, cited under ISEP 6.19 with the corrective plan approved on
4/18/2022.
FOM 801-C Medical Passport.
7

Initial medical passport:
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following.
Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child’s current and complete health information
4 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation that the medical passport was
provided to the caregiver within two weeks of the child’s initial placement or
the child’s replacement moves on 2/2/2023, 8/18/2023 and 10/20/2023. Nor
were medical passports generated for 2023.
• A second record did not show documentation of medical passports for 2023.
• A third record did not show documentation of medical passport generated
between 7/27/2023 and 1/30/2024.
• A fourth record did not show documentation of the medical passport being
provided to the child’s caregiver within two weeks of the child’s 9/8/2023
initial placement or replacement on 9/19/2023.
• A fifth record did not show documentation of a medical passport due for
October 2023.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023; and during the 2022 Interim
inspection, with the corrective plan approved on 4/18/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Nothing this inspection.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas.
Policy 722-8D Treatment plan:
• The agency was re-advised when indicating on the treatment plans that
the document was mailed to a parent, or that the worker was unable to
8

locate the parent including the date of that action on the plan may aid it in
showing compliance to the standard.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan during this
licensing period. This correction plan related to the agency’s 2023 Renewal
Inspection where it received the following violations:
• R400.12405(5)(a) & (b)Change of Placement.
• R400.12418(2)(b) Development of Service Plans.
• R400.12419(1)(c) Initial Service Plans.
• R400.12419(1)(h) Initial Service plans
• R400.12420(1)(g) Updated Service Plans.
• ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS (Commitment 22).
• ISEP 6.19(5) (c) Assessment & service Plans Content
(Commitment 69).
• FOM 722-06B- Family Team Meeting.
• FOM 722-08- Case Service Plans-Overview, Types & Timeframes-
Supervisory Approval.
• FOM 722-08 D Treatment Plans-Agreements & Signatures
• FOM 722-09- Updated service plan approval.
• FOM 722-8-EFoster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary.
• FOM 722-15 Discharge Documents.
• FOM 801-C Medical Passport.
• FOM 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and
Developmental needs of Children under MDHHS
The agency made some progress on that corrective action plan but were not
completely successful with it as indicated by the repeat violations documented in
this report. The agency provided documentation showing proofs of its efforts to
continue training its staff on services requirements and to have topics like FTMs,
service plans, social work contacts, medical passports as an ongoing agenda
items.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted an annual chief administrator's report dated 1/19/2024 and I
reviewed that report and spoke with the chief administrator about it. The agency
amended the report to better address the section of the report reflective of the
9

agency’s assessment of its last annual inspection noncompliance; and to provide
more detail related to unplanned child moves and disruptions. The revised report
adhered to all required standards.
Financial Overview
Not applicable. This is a Department of Health and Human Services district office.
Staff Interviews
In addition to discussion with the chief administrator, and four of the administrative
staff during the entrance conference, related to the last inspection’s corrective action
plan, new staff, and the agency’s current challenges, and status/program functioning I
interviewed three foster care staff. The staff reported positives, related to working
for this district office, team work, flexibility, likable coworkers and managers, good
communication and the administration seeking to provide them assistance. Areas
of needs or concerns indicated were, a desire for new staff to be hired, inclusive of
more social service aides, possible specialization for some worker service areas,
and more resources to aid and support birth parents around transportation and
physical needs.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency did not reveal any difficulties or safety concerns.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert. The alert was received on 12/19/2023.
Concern:
The DCWL Analyst indicated there was an insufficient number of beds for occupants
in the home, The agency was asked to clarify if the children are residing in the home
of the relative.
Resolution:
The agency indicated their worker had visited the home on 11/28/2023 at which time
the three children placed in the home were observed to have a double bed adequate
for the children’s bedding. On 12/19/2023 the agency contacted the relative about
the bedding situation. The relative reported that she gave the bed to her daughter
on 12/7/2023; a matter which was not relayed to the foster care worker. On
12/19/20123 the agency safety planned and placed an order for a bunk bed set and
an additional twin bed. The relative was purchasing air mattresses for the children
pending the arrival of the beds and delivering and setting them up in the home on
12/19/2023. All beds were delivered to the home as of 1/4/2024; and were being put
together as of 1/12/224. Pictures of the air mattresses, and the beds were provided.
The agency also educated the relative regarding the importance of making sure any
changes in the home are immediately reported to the MDHHS (Michigan Department
of Health and Humans Services ).
10

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
February 16, 2024
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 1, 2024
________________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Area Manager
11
